Kronecker's construction defines an extension field by taking the quotient of the polynomial ring of the base field by the ideal generated by an irreducible polynomial. The residue class of the indeterminate in this quotient field is a zero of the polynomial, allowing the successive adjoining of zeros of polynomials to the base field.
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
Does the concept of a/an Kronecker's Construction need to be defined for a definition of a/an K-homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a K-homomorphism involves a field homomorphism between two field extensions that restricts to the identity map on the base field K. This definition is self-contained and does not inherently require any specific method of constructing the field extensions, such as Kronecker's construction. Kronecker's construction is a method for creating field extensions by adjoining roots of polynomials, but it is not the only method for constructing such extensions. The definition of a K-homomorphism is applicable regardless of how the field extensions L and L' are constructed, as long as they are extensions of the same base field K. Therefore, the concept of Kronecker's construction is not necessary for the definition of a K-homomorphism to make sense.
